reviewText: This is a poorly produced Scout presentation.  The storyline is very broken and difficult to follow.  I bought it on a recommendation and did not preview it before showing it to some Scouts on  a recent bus trip.  We watched one episode and did not see any more.
Haven't had a chance to watch this one, but if it is as much fun as the other old movies we got at Christmas, we should enjoy it.

I really am glad that I got it. It shows you where the B.S.A. came from and how strong it was. I wish the scout of today were more like this. Not so poltiticaly correct worry minded and yet stright honest and strong.

I recomend this movie, a little old but  so worth it. I am glad I got it.

`~John
My Boy Scouts had a good time watching this.  Many never saw one of the serials which appeared in theaters.

Remember when scouting was all about leadership training and giving boys a chance to prove their mettle? That's what this cliffhanger is about: Great things done by boys with courage and grit looking for adventure. A troop, they learn, is where a boy can prove his courage. A gang is where a boy goes to hide.
Jackie Cooper stars.

This is one serial that has it all...lost treasure, lost Indian tribe, lost ghost town!!! Jackie Cooper leads his troop in defeating gangsters bent on securing untold-of wealth! Great chapter endings...over the falls, collasping suspension bridge, mangled by stampeding hordes, etc...Family frendly adventure romp & a fun serial to boot!
Sometimes the Universial serials get overlooked for being too plot-driven as opposed to the action-packed slick Republic product or the simplistic/cartoonish Columbia product...but, I will say that Scouts To The Rescue delivers on all cylinders!!!
Just enough plot...enough humor...enough thrills to keep fans coming back week after week.
A highly enjoyable viewing experience...Enjoy!!!

VCI Entertainment and Universal Pictures present..."Scouts to the Rescue" (1939) (Dolby digitally remastered), a 12 Chapter cliffhanger from a thrilling adventure of breath taking exploits and suspenseful Universal serial featuring a good cast --- Starring Jackie Cooper, David Durand, Bill Cody Jr, Vondell Darr,William Ruhl and Sidney Miller --- Directed by Alan James and Ray Taylor and released in November 5, 1939, our story line and film has the leader of Martinsville Troop No. One, Eagle Scout Bruce Scott (Jackie Cooper) searching for buried treasure with a map supplied by new scout Skeets Scanlon (Bill Cody Jr)....what is this hidden treasure in "Ghost Town" that the scout pack have uncovered, and why are the counterfeiters also interested in this new find...what tribe of Indians are living in the mountains who have been lost for centuries and are now witnessing civilization closing in on them....can G-Man Hal Marvin (William Ruhl) breakup this counterfeiting ring of Pug O'Toole (Ralph Dunn) and Doc (Jason Robards Sr) who are ready to go to press...will Jackie Cooper save the bacon of everyone concerned in this 12 chapter play and keep Universal Pictures in the forefront of weekly serial cliffhangers...don't leave the theater until the final chapter is over and done with "The Boy Scouts Triumph"....just remember double thrills, chills, mystery and suspense...hitting the bull's eye with excitement...don't miss a single spine thrilling episode..return next week to this local theater for another episode of action and adventure that will keep you thrilled until the next chapter.

Under director's Ray Taylor and Alan James, associate producer Henry MacRae, screenplay by George Pympton, Basil Dickey, Wyndham Gittens and Joseph Poland, original story by Irving Crump of "Boys Life" magazine, dialogue director Ella O'Neill, musical score by Charles Previn, stunts by Eddie Parker (stunt double for William Ruhl)...the cast includes Jackie Cooper (Bruce Scott), David Durand (Rip Rawson), Vondell Darr (Mary Scanlon), Edwin Stanley (Pat Scanlon), William Ruhl (G- Man Hal Marvin), Bill Cody Jr (Skeets Scanlon), Sidney Miller (Hermie/a Scout), Ivan Miller (Turk Mortensen), Ralph Dunn (Pug/henchman), George Regas (Lukolu/high priest), Jack Mulhall (Scoutmaster Hale), Jason Robards Sr (Doc/henchman), Dick Botiller (Leeka/leader of warriors), Tom Steele (Runaway surry driver), Eddie Parker (Joe/rider with message), Franklin Delano Roosevelt (Himself/archive footage), Iron Eyes Cody (Indian), Victor Adams (Hurst/hencman)........special footnote, actor Jackie Cooper playing "Daily Planet" editor Perry White is one of only four actors to appear in all four "Superman" films (the others were Christopher Reeves, Margot Kidder & Marc McClure), Cooper up to the present 2005 is the youngest actor to be nominated for "Best Actor in a Leading Role" at the Academy Awards........meanwhile back to our Universal Serial which is always good till the last drop and this serial is no exception...there is a great deal of entertainment here for the cliffhanger fans out there...all courtesy of VCI Entertainment, who in my humble opinion is the best there is in restoring early serials and features.

BIOS:

1. Jackie Cooper (aka John Cooperman Jr)

Birth Date: 9/15/1922 - Los Angeles, California

Status: (still living as of 2005)

2. Sidney Miller

Date of Birth: 22 October 1916 - Shenandoah, Pennsylvania

Date of Death: 10 January 2004 - Los Angeles, California

3. Alan James (Director)

Date of Birth: 23 March 1890 - Port Townsend, Washington

Date of Death: 30 December 1952 - Hollywood, California

4. Ray Taylor (Director)

Date of Birth: 1 December 1888 - Perham, Minnesota

Date of Death: 15 February 1952 - Hollywood, California

CHAPTER TITLES:

1. Death Rides the Air

2. Avalanche of Doom

3. Trapped by the Indians

4. River of Doom

5. Descending Doom

6. Ghost Town Menace

7. Destroyed by Dynamite

8. Thundering Hoofs

9. The Fire God Strikes

10. The Battle of Ghost Town

11. Hurtling Through Space

12. The Boy Scouts Triumph

27. Winners of the West (Dick Foran, Harry Woods, Roy Barcroft & Charles Stevens)

28. Zane Greys "King of the Royal Mounted" (Allan "Rocky" Lane)

29. Zorro's Cliffhanger Collection (Reed Hadley, John Carroll & Linda Stirling)

Great job by VCI Entertainment for releasing "Scouts to the Rescue" (1939), the digital transfere with a clean, clear and crisp print...looking forward to more high quality releases from the vintage serial era of the '30s, '40s & '50s...order your copy now from Amazon or VCI Entertainment where there are plenty of copies available on DVD, stay tuned once again for top notch action mixed with deadly adventure from the "King of Serials" VCI...just the way we like 'em

Total Time: 235 mins on DVD ~ VCI Entertainment 8484 ~ (5/29/2007)

This was good, a 12 part boy scout action/adventure series.  If you are involved in Boy Scouts you will appreciate.  We showed this at a YMCA Lock in our Troop did, and a lot of the boys really got into it.  I purchase all of these old scout videos I find, this one was definetely unique.

Growing up in Massachusetts during the fifties and being from the first generation of T.V. My generation were fortunate to see movies from the thirties and forties on T.V. WBZTV in Boston showed a 5pm movie every monday through Friday. The allotted time fram was one and a half hours. Sometimes the movie ended early and the remains time slot would be filled with a "chapter" of a serial. You never got to see the entire serial. I loved the cliff hanger endings. Today I am 68 years old and have a massive movie library. My movies are in every genre and range from 1936 to 2016. I have 75 serials and have just watched scouts.

Hats off to VCI for the restoration work on the serials. They are from a time gone by and are not only a very important part of American film history but more important, a piece of American culture and morality that has faded away.
my scout son thought this was funny! Recommend to scouts
reakl cheesey movie as a scout leader its interesting to see how the rules we live by were not in place back then

This movie is just so much fun for the entire family, especially if you or someone you know is a scouter.
It is a must have.
